title: Woman finds cheating partner is engaged 4 weeks after they broke up
text:
“He continued to deny it - until I used my sneaky fake Facebook to look up his profile."

Cheating can be hurtful and confusing. But it's rarely just about sex.

Looking back on the relationship, there were hundreds of tiny details that never felt quite right.

The way he started turning away in bed to check his phone, the fact that she seemed to know everything about your relationship, the number of times they just happened to run into each other.

But it’s surprising what you can teach yourself to ignore, simply because you don’t want to face the truth.

In *Emma’s case, the truth was even more heartbreaking – because the man cheating on her was her childhood best friend.

“They were friends for maybe a year - that much I knew,” she shared on Reddit.

“I first started having suspicions back in May and he told me it was nothing.”

Read how this woman discovered her partner had been cheating after their daughter's first birthday and the mum whose entire 10-year marriage was a lie.

“I don't know what to feel. I feel, numb honestly." Source: iStock

"I don't know what to feel"

By September, Emma could no longer pretend that nothing was happening between her partner and his "friend".

She immediately ended things - and then three days later he confessed that he and this other woman had been seeing each other for a month.

As hurtful as that confession was – things were about to get a hell of a lot worse for Emma.

“I shouldn't have done it but I used my sneaky fake Facebook to look up his profile, he's blocked on my real one. He's asked her to marry him, and she said 'yes',” she said.

“I don't know what to feel. I feel, numb honestly.

“27 days after I found out about the cheating and she's his wife-to-be. There's very little chance this whole thing started a mere month before we broke up."

"She gets his name and his ring"

There’s also a part of Emma that wonders why he chose to propose to this other woman instead of her.

“We never married despite being together since 2017,” she said.

“It feels in a way like I'm being punished for not accepting his cheating and lying.

“Like he wants to marry her right away because she's blinder than I was ...or something.

“Obviously he lied so much to us both. But she gets his name and his ring.”

The other woman gets his name and his ring - leaving Emma to wonder what else she'd like to take. Source: Pinterest

“How long did this actually go on for?"

The entire thing has left Emma completely humiliated, with hundreds of unanswered questions.

“How long did this actually go on for?” she asked.

“Did they seriously get engaged after two months? Or had they been going on for months when I begged him for the truth?

“Maybe even longer? I'll never know.

“It bothers me to think I was lead on for so much longer than I was, which was already too long to begin with."

Emma has no idea how she will ever meet someone decent. Source: Pinterest

"He gave her everything he promised me"

Emma is left looking for a way to start again – armed with the knowledge that even your childhood best friend is capable of cheating.

“Will I EVER be able to marry without being cheated on first?” she asked.

“It's like either they cheat and get mad at you for getting mad at them.

“Or they cheat, you get mad and leave, so they find someone else more forgiving.

“And give them everything they promised you.”

We're pretty convinced that Emma's ex's relationship will end like this. Source: Pinterest

"They will never work"

Commenters were quick to reassure Emma that her ex’s engagement won’t work – regardless of how long he had secretly been seeing the other woman.

“I see the name and the ring as the equivalent of getting a set of steak knives in a game show,” one man said.

“Yeah, they will never work,” another added.

“Allow me to be the first to introduce you to the term... narcissist,” a woman said.

“No normal person gets engaged in a month. Sorry, don't come at me with your anecdotes. You simply do not know anything about a person in that amount of time.”

“Doesn't it look like a desperate attempt to hold together something that's clearly falling apart?” a woman questioned.

“There is nothing to be jealous of, they're making a mess and luckily you're not a part of it.”
description: “He continued to deny it - until I used my sneaky fake Facebook to look up his profile."
